content.question: The base of a solid is the region in the first quadrant bounded by the graph of <math alttext="y equals, 2 x, minus x squared" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>âˆ’</mo><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> and the <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-axis. For the solid, each cross section perpendicular to the <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-axis is a square. What is the volume of the solid?

topic.text: 8.7: Volumes with Cross Sections - Squares and Rectangles
